description: From Middle English tradicioun, from Old French tradicion, from Latin trāditiō, from the verb trādō. Doublet of treason.

entries.meaning: A part of culture that is passed from person to person or generation to generation, possibly differing in detail from family to family, such as the way to celebrate holidays.
An established or distinctive style or method:
The act of delivering into the hands of another; delivery.
examples: A deed takes effect only from this tradition or delivery; for, if the date be false or impossible, the delivery ascertains the time of it.

verbs.description: tradition (third-person singular simple present traditions, present participle traditioning, simple past and past participle traditioned)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To transmit by way of tradition; to hand down.
examples: The following story is  […]  traditioned with very much credit amongst our English Catholics.
